thread.title: Stephen Decatur boys basketball holds off Wilde Lake for 3A East region championship
thread.title_full: Stephen Decatur boys basketball holds off Wilde Lake for 3A East region championship

author: Brent Kennedy
title: Stephen Decatur boys basketball holds off Wilde Lake for 3A East region championship
text:
Stephen Decatur boys basketball holds off Wilde Lake for 3A East region championship Stephen Decatur boys basketball beats Wilde Lake for 3A East region title 
Stephen Decatur guard Kevon Voyles talks about the Seahawks' 65-55 victory over Wilde Lake in the 3A East region championship game on Saturday, March 4. 
Stephen Decatur guard Kevon Voyles talks about the Seahawks' 65-55 victory over Wilde Lake in the 3A East region championship game on Saturday, March 4. ... (Brent Kennedy) 
Wilde Lake (17-9) did get within three points once more early in the third quarter, following a foul shot from Nick David (15 points), but simply never managed to get over the hump. Stephen Decatur put together a 9-0 run toward the end of the period to help establish a 12-point advantage, 48-36, entering the fourth quarter. 
From there, clutch efforts from the team’s seniors — including Gary Briddell (15 points) and Keve Aluma (13) — made sure that Wilde Lake never got closer than eight points the rest of the way. 
“Our veteran players were the difference tonight … there was a sense of been there, done that when things got tight. They had that determination, knowing they didn’t want to lose this game,” Johnson said. “I had confidence the entire time that they were going to come up with the big plays when we needed them.” Caption Wilde Lake boys basketball beats River Hill in 3A East quarterfinals 
Wilde Lake Boys Basketball players Marquis Bullett and Trea Keys talk about the Wildecats' 43-35 win over River Hill in the 3A East region quarterfinals on Tuesday, Feb. 28. (Brent Kennedy, Baltimore Sun Media Group) 
Wilde Lake Boys Basketball players Marquis Bullett and Trea Keys talk about the Wildecats' 43-35 win over River Hill in the 3A East region quarterfinals on Tuesday, Feb. 28. (Brent Kennedy, Baltimore Sun Media Group) Caption Wilde Lake boys basketball beats River Hill in 3A East quarterfinals 
Wilde Lake Boys Basketball players Marquis Bullett and Trea Keys talk about the Wildecats' 43-35 win over River Hill in the 3A East region quarterfinals on Tuesday, Feb. 28. (Brent Kennedy, Baltimore Sun Media Group) 
Wilde Lake Boys Basketball players Marquis Bullett and Trea Keys talk about the Wildecats' 43-35 win over River Hill in the 3A East region quarterfinals on Tuesday, Feb. 28. (Brent Kennedy, Baltimore Sun Media Group) Caption Stephen Decatur boys basketball beats Wilde Lake for 3A East region title 
Stephen Decatur guard Kevon Voyles talks about the Seahawks' 65-55 victory over Wilde Lake in the 3A East region championship game on Saturday, March 4. 
Stephen Decatur guard Kevon Voyles talks about the Seahawks' 65-55 victory over Wilde Lake in the 3A East region championship game on Saturday, March 4. Caption Wilde Lake boys basketball beats Centennial in 3A East semifinals 
Wilde Lake senior Nick David talks about the Wildecats' 48-43 win over Centennial in the 3A East region semifinals on Thursday, March 2. (Brent Kennedy/Howard County Times) 
Wilde Lake senior Nick David talks about the Wildecats' 48-43 win over Centennial in the 3A East region semifinals on Thursday, March 2. (Brent Kennedy/Howard County Times) Caption Centennial vs. Long Reach boys basketball playoffs 
Centennial senior Elijah White talks about the Eagles' 61-57 win over Long Reach in the 3A East quarterfinal on Tuesday, Feb. 28 in Elicott City. White finished with 15 points in the outing. (Monica D'Ippolito/BSMG) 
Centennial senior Elijah White talks about the Eagles' 61-57 win over Long Reach in the 3A East quarterfinal on Tuesday, Feb. 28 in Elicott City. White finished with 15 points in the outing. (Monica D'Ippolito/BSMG) Caption Long Reach vs. Reservoir boys basketball playoffs 
Long Reach's Tre'von Morgan talks about the Lightning's 58-53 first round playoff win over Reservoir on Friday, Feb. 24 at Reservoir High School. Morgan led his team with a game-high 16 points. (Monica D'Ippolito/BSMG). 
Long Reach's Tre'von Morgan talks about the Lightning's 58-53 first round playoff win over Reservoir on Friday, Feb. 24 at Reservoir High School. Morgan led his team with a game-high 16 points. (Monica D'Ippolito/BSMG). 
On the other side, while his team fell short, Wilde Lake coach Deon Wingfield had nothing but praise for the heart his players showed in defeat. After falling behind by double digits early in the second quarter, the Wildecats clawed their way back. 
In addition to David, Trea Keys (team-high 17 points) and Marquis Bullett (13) each played key roles in the team getting itself into a one-possession game by the late stages of the first half. 
“I told my kids just now how proud I am of them that they never backed down, even as we fell behind early,” Wingfield said. “Once we settled down, realized that we were capable of playing with this team, we were able to get ourselves back into it. You could see that confidence grow and, although we fell short, the effort was there.” 
While disappointed in the final outcome, Wingfield added that this was a big step for the program this year — especially with a strong young core returning next winter. 
“This stings, but we have a great young nucleus and I’m hoping it makes them hungry,” Wingfield said. “And I thank our seniors so much for setting the bar. They have established now how the program is going to be and it’s up to the guys coming back to carry that torch.” 
Stephen Decatur is now headed back to the University of Maryland’s Xfinity Center for a state semifinal match-up against Baltimore-Poly on Thursday, March 9 at 3 p.m. Last year, the team made it to the state championship game before losing in overtime against C. Milton Wright. 
Prior to that, the team had won just one region title in the previous 25 years. 
“You know, there has been a lot of pressure on this group because everyone expected us to get back there and anything less than that was going to be a disappointment. And it’s not easy to win a region title, you just have to look at how long it had been before we did it last year,” Johnson said. “So we’re excited to be going back [to the state semifinals] and we know it’s going to be tough — there are some great teams left — but I believe in these guys.” 
Stephen Decatur 65, Wilde Lake 55 
SD (25-1): Voyles 19, Briddell 15, Aluma 13, Johnson 12, Frasier 4, Woodland 2. 
WL (17-9): Keys 17, David 15, Bullett 13, Barnes 5, Joseph 5. 
Half: 31-25 SD.
